NJe46X9wO6TxhQ8Khv2P5A.text: A slightly better than average, but just as overpriced, over-hyped "hotel bar." Went on a busy night and waited about an hour to get in (waited in the even more mediocre bar upstairs), and then at least 15 minutes for service contact and another 20 for the drinks. Our server seemed more like an Eat-N-Park waitress dressed like a prostitute than a steward of fine libations. I think I had the "Blind Tiger" which was fine, but not better than cocktails I make at home and not worth the wait.

N2trcXKqjgGtKzgc5U0UuA.text: Dawn, the face of this operation, and behind the scenes too, is a fantastic bartender. When I arrived to meet my boyfriend and his friend, Dawn was explaining to them about the gin rickey cocktail and the gimlet. I started asking her more about the gimlet and said in hadn't had cheery in a gimlet ever. I then proceeded to look at the menu and then informed Dawn I had made my choice. She looked at me and said "let me guess". After a few seconds of her feeling into my selection and personality she said "apricot gimlet". By golly she was right! Dawn has that magical bartender intuition that only someone who understands people and well thought out crafted cocktails could have.  After being there for a 15 minutrs or so, she brought us complimentary warm spiced almonds. The apricot gimlet was very nice, not too atrong or sweet, it was balanced and refreshing. also makes a nice old fashioned. We will be going back because to Dawn.

COLpMZEGxhF04MyunQez9A.text: Came here after a overly busy Butcher and the Rye.  Wow.....and what a relief.  This was exactly what I wanted.  Easy to hear yourself talk and outstanding drinks.  I had the Egg Flip as well as the Orange/Lemon Old Tom Cobbler.  Both great.  The Cobbler tasted so refreshing it would have been a great beach drink.  We also got a Charcuterie board which was good, but wasn't a fan of the Pate (and I usually like Pate)  I never knew this place existed until my friend showed it to me.  I'm so glad I know about it now.  I feel like I'm giving up this secret gem.  A place for great drinks and conversation.

UB19ofbKajMcLP9t_bGKzA.text: Awwwww man, our owners have such a great time whenever they come here. There is something special about the tipsy feeling resulting from drinks made with painstaking care and fine ingredients. Our waiter is always exceptionally courteous and cordial. Our owners previously had a really special Mother's Day that ended at the Speakeasy, instantly making a lasting memory for grandma and our owners. It is always so much fun to share a hidden gem of a destination like this to a loved one. Our owners will come way more often when they start making millions of dollars off of internet videos of our hilarious antics. Until then, our owners can only justify getting $10+ drinks a few times a year. Meow.

uARRI0onlieoVptWczU8mg.text: Do not come to this place! Waited in line for 30 min to be welcomed by a 'manager' who said we could not in,although the door attendant told us it was our turn. The room was VERY warm! The waitress took our menus away before we were ready to order...our drinks were TERRIBLE! Our waitress came to check on us..re-made the 'supposed' Negroni..tasted much better!!!  bad experience turned into an 'ok' experience..they seemed to be under staffed this evening....

veMQ847dabR1mTJVA4AMYw.text: I went to the speakeasy bar in the omni last night. It was amazing! Five stars! The bartender was knowledgeable about everything and we were the last ones to leave the bar. The bartender's name is Dawn and Ben is the manager. The ambiance is so chill that it makes you feel like you went back in time to the early 19 hundreds. The room is a little bit small otherwise the place is perfect. The drinks are made it with fresh ingredients and the aroma from your drink what have you guessing which ingredient is making that smell.

BfpqmL6OyDwrzRTxquHlnA.text: Very cool little place in the basement of the Omni. Definitely an old school vibe type spot. Dawn the bartender was awesome. Try the Moscow Mule or just tell her what you like and she'll whip you up something. Worth a visit.

rHWVV7JRoqpdSEUshal19Q.text: Drinks are above average (fair priced for the quality) and staff is friendly, however after a couple times visits, I can confirm the service is always ridiculously slow (a minimum of 5 min wait time for a drink, sometimes almost 10 min after ordering).  Your drink is always dry for several min before being able to order again.  If they improved service time I would easily give 5 stars.

7F5Jp9bMYdECWNBBOm90bQ.text: Service was poor. Long wait for a drink even though it wasn't busy. Worst old fashioned I've had! Much better options

1MHscgXzyim1eyMQiGX_GQ.text: I normally don't write bad reviews on places because I'm in the industry and I usually give the place the benefit of the doubt but this one didn't make the cut. Both of us got the punch which doesn't actually need to be made. At around 25 minutes of waiting, the server came up to our table saying the bartender was going to get a refill on the punch... Yes, 25 minutes later. When the drinks showed up, they were two different ones when we both ordered the same thing. Keep in mind we are approaching about 35 minutes for two punch drinks. We figured we should ask for our tab because it was obviously going to take a while to get it. 20 minutes later our tab comes and without looking, I give him my card because I didn't have the patience any more. The credit card slip came and I was charged $26 for two $9 drinks. As I said my patience were depleted so I didn't bother to dispute the charge. All of this could have been changed if the server would have acknowledged the long wait time but he didn't in any way. I won't be returning to Speakeasy.

PmZAjnTOL1yGlJNQdBatGg.text: Cool atmosphere (Brilliant True history) - could be a little darker and include some live music at least one night a week.

ExumRfhurthEXeP4-d_mtA.text: Absolutely amazing place. It felt like we were in the 1920's. The drinks, lighting, and decor were perfect. It's a small place, small enough to make you feel like you're in an actual speakeasy, but not cramped. The decor is ornate, but doesn't feel stuffy. The manager and our waiter were very kind and welcoming. We felt that they genuinely wanted us to have a great time. The best part is that this was actually a speakeasy in the 1920s! I recommend highly!

Oju02BlS6VFGygsS5oYN6A.text: The place itself is a cool location and I liked the decor but that's about it. When I first arrived I looked around an noticed most people were drinking beer or wine. I thought that was odd since this was a place that was supposed to specialize in prohibition style cocktails, but after I ordered my first drink I realized why.  I got an old fashioned that was hands down the worst old fashioned I have ever had, everything was off about it including the bar tender shoving about half an orange in it. Next up I got a Tom Collins and when it arrived it was black, I have never seen this before and the drink itself was horrendous. Nothing that goes into a Tom Collins would make the drink black.  I heard other patrons complain to the bartender about their drinks not being right and she would dismiss their concerns immediately and say things like you probably never had this style of drink before. This place really needs to hire a bartender that is passionate and knows about making these type of drinks. Bottom line if you are looking for a prohibition style drink avoid this place there are places like Acacia or Butcher in the Rye that are a million times better.

fGLJmkH0Gp5IJrlxnqcOxA.text: Great setting in a fine hotel. Was looking for some classic drinks in a quiet classy old school setting with a good friend. We had other options - but we chose Speakeasy.   Unfortunately we were turned away 20 minutes before closing despite being guests of the hotel and dressed in business attire. We were not some dudes in ball caps going in to grab a few bottles of Bud and think we are big time. Nor were we prima donnas seeking to have the entire staff stay past 11 so we could milk our one cocktail. With 20 minutes to go - the staff could have politely informed us that it was last call.  Plenty of time for everyone to do it right.  We could have joined the 8-9 other customers and all would have left at closing. Instead we were turned away with the bum's rush and we  never considered the place again in our remaining evenings in the city.  I know it's hard being in the service business near the end of a shift. However - that's part of the job. Try coming up with a solution that allows you to serve the customer without breaking the system rather than ending a potentially positive relationship before it begins.

H5roZczlwK_dbrKOxiPn-Q.text: Pittsburgh's first attempt at a quality speakeasy was a solid attempt.  The decor was certainly on par, however some of their cocktails fall short.  If you are going to brand yourself as a True "speakeasy", value the quality of your ingredients and your craft.  This may be that I live in New York and am accustom to speakeasy's of the like of EO and Death&Co.  nonetheless, solid attempt on their part and they will be a trail blazer for the Pittsburgh cocktail scene but they have a long way to go.

5-I9ICzGc7ALBvI39kz00A.text: Dawn (the bartender) was great - as was the atmosphere. The bourbon old fashioned was excellent.

RSBgsnUUQV0c7229qSu0gQ.text: Drink menu was unique, full of old fashioned recipes with a modern twist. Awesome John Collins - made with Jameson. Great laid back atmosphere.  Excellent!

X6W-oVy9JOFZadkXOJpBUw.text: Cool atmosphere. Definitely worth a drop by for the ambience alone.  Food plays it's purpose. Nothing bad to say about it.  Thinking about the times this place has experienced gave it a good energy for me. Definitely recommend a trip if you're in the area.

j9dSvwh-Q9JZmJD85-oyvQ.text: Not my favorite prohibition bar that I've ever been to but it is certainly cool.  It is in the basement of the William Penn Hotel and was apparently originally a real speakeasy during prohibition.  I talked to the bartender a bit and found out that the place was not even discovered until about a year ago when they found a False wall during hotel renovations!  There were also three unopened bottles of liquor dating from the early 1900's that are now on display.  The drinks are all reminiscent of 1920 style cocktails.  Very cool.  Don't expect your drink fast, these bartenders know what they are doing and take their time making your drink look and taste perfect.  Waiting is easy though when the surroundings that you are in are very well done and there is old fashion music playing throughout.  I would definitely go back here though.  Be careful how many drinks you order here.  There prices are quite expensive.

x_KGLDhjFZqvNrw9PY_RIQ.text: George should be commended for exhibiting outstanding service to our party of 9  on a busy Friday night! Good vibe and great cocktail selection!

YoGAomJv5FqOKFLwmIkkYQ.text: I don't know where to begin.  How do you begin to call yourself a speakeasy when you are this bad at making drinks?  Worst Old Fashioned and Negroni I've ever had.  They didn't have proper whiskey ice or glassware, but its called Speakeasy.  Whiskey ice cube?  Too much to ask.  50% Seltzer water in an old fashioned? Since when?  This all is of course in addition, super-super slow service.  Took us approximately 20 minutes to get all 6 drinks (party of 6) and ironically, the last person to get their drink (me) was the only person who ordered their whiskey neat.  I guess they had to call corporate to figure out what "neat" means.  Will not go back.  Ever.

KG9C-jEdyvQ0JjySfeio_A.text: Lovely space, brilliant menu with plenty of fun facts on the history of speak-easies and specific information about Pittsburgh during prohibition. Local pride is instilled in the drinks and the anecdotes in the menu. LOVE! Get your tail down here during their limited opening of Thursday thru--Saturday? It better be here when I visit next, ok?

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States
Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. From their awesome menu.
Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States

2YLfh8TywiFFC6qn_sssuA.text: Excited about another first review!  Met up with a friend here for cocktails during the Christmas break.  True to form for speakeasies, you have to go down a set of stairs to enter the bar.  Granted down a staircase in one of most ornate hotels in the downtown and is well lit and plush.  Overall first impression of the venue is that it's decorated very nicely; however they need to tone down the lighting, I would say by half to get  a real speakeasy feeling.  Drink prices are right on par with some of the priciest joints in San Francisco so it will be interesting to see how well it does for the next few months.  $14 for a Manhattan is just too much for this market.  I don't even pay that much for some of the best Manhattans in San Francisco (Burrit Room, House of Shields, etc)  Service was great.  George was a doll and very attentive to our group.  Drinks, just one round were decent, I had a hot buttered rum kind of drink, but the one I had a bit later at Meat & Potato was much tastier.  So it's just the early stages and I think they'll get their groove on as the months pass and I'll keep it in my radar for future visits to da Burgh.

WcgOtLaP3FOHD8BnwHw88A.text: I'm surprised about previous reviews on bad service. The only one in this joint with bad service is the manager. The employees are amazing and very welcoming. Dom made excellent drinks. All I know was I wanted  bourbon and she made me several amazing cocktails.  The manager does his own thing and is of zero importance.

nYewn8-Cqd2TJcdODUSN5A.text: Horrible service. Not sure I can put it any other way. Just horrible. Compared to the excellent hotel it is in, even more so. The service was so bad we just left without our drinks. Place has potential, but they need to look at their staff to see if they can get a drink to a table within 20 minutes. Too bad.

qv1fDRWbEu3zfCS8lr8FEg.text: Loved the ambiance!  Very dimly lit, tho.  Our waiter was very helpful and took the time to describe many of the drinks.  The prohibition era menu was very unique.  I tried the absinthe, can't compare it to anything because I've never had it before, but it had a licorice flavor.  My friend had a port wine and it was sweet and smooth.

MJiKgDuOjENBuXier12Hlw.text: Being a parent of three, the babysitter situations don't always become available as often as Mama and I would like.  When the opportunities do arise for a grown-ups only date night, I need to make the most of it to ensure I get another date night in the near future - if you get my gist.  Lets add to that challenge by having date night on Valentines Day, dinner at a restaurant we have never tried, and after dinner drinks at a place neither of us had ever heard of.  Now that the scene of this story has been set and the bar has been set to 'impress the little lady or sleep with the dog tonight' we begin at the William Penn Hotel at the doors of the Speakeasy.  When we arrived, we were met by a very friendly gentleman who promptly informed us, in a very apologetic manner, that he was at capacity and couldn't let us in.  Thinking that this was simply part of the experience, we figured we needed a password.  When 'Capone is a two-bit hooch jockey' and 'twenty-FOUR skadoo' didn't work, we regrouped for a quick powder.  After loitering around in the hallway and pretending to be interested in the wall paper, all the while watching the 'bouncer' gently reject large groups of finely dressed Monopoly Men and trophy wives, we got in and were seated right at the bar.  Immediately upon entering, you felt a different atmosphere in the joint, but not in a bad way.  The room was warmer than in the hall and you could feel that this was a place that was never intended to be occupied, much like a hide-away that would have been ideal for a prohibition party.  The lights were low, and big band, swing, and jazz music were playing setting the soundtrack for the night.   Groups were seated around small tables in velvet lined chairs, sipping period-inspired drinks like Rob-Roys, Gibsons, and MONhattans.  Couples at the bar enjoyed trying new drinks and overlapping the experience with new friends, all the while preserving the close, intimate conversation or to simply wind down at after a raucous evening of fast-paced stunt-swing dancing!  The entire experience to this point was made complete by Dawn, the bartender, who not only made us feel very welcome, but she took our picture to preserve the memory.  Dawn took the time to tell us about the menu, the history of the room, and we marveled watching her mix drinks.  After reviewing the menu, Mama and I each opted for Moscow Mules with the house blend, citrus infused vodka and slapped rosemary.  Slapped rosemary?  As unconventional as us 'nightlife rubes' thought that was, it presented a wonderful flavor to an amazing drink.  Before we knew it, we were engaged in conversation and being able to complete thoughts without being asked for a snack (parents know what I'm talking about).  We didn't try any food, hence I'm only compelled to give four stars.  I'm sure when we make it back, that will be raised to five, especially since I had my eye on the duck charcuterie and Mama wants to taste absinthe.  So as we close out our evening and head back to reality Mama and I both agreed that the Speakeasy was the perfect place to close out a romantic evening...and yes, the dog slept alone!!

bA_9Dfc19kv7uQ2xMz-75Q.text: My wife and I were celebrating our anniversary in Pittsburgh and we're staying at the Omni. We wandered down to the Speakeasy around 10pm and had to wait in a short line to get in, since the bar can only hold so many people at a time. We waited about 10 minutes and were let in. I ordered a Speakeasy Scotch and my wife had a Tom Collins. As we waited for our drinks, I took in the ambience. It's pretty cool in the Speakeasy and was a nice semi-intimate place for drinks to close out the evening. Got our drinks after a short wait, which was forgivable since it was a busy Saturday night. My Speakeasy Scotch was great and heavy on the scotch (thank you) and my wife's Tom Collins had pineapple in it -- different than the advertised Maraschino Cherries in the menu. We left after one round of drinks which turned out to be just fine. I know all hotel bars are expensive, but we paid more for our two drinks here than we did at Primanti Bros for our entire meal the next day. There are certainly cheaper bars to drink at in the city, but the Speakeasy isn't a bad choice if you're at the Omni and don't feel like venturing out into the city.

LWk2I2QB6kNIXTeCQUNX8w.text: Dawn, the bartender, is the real deal. After two wonderful cocktails (gin and rum), I told her to just surprise me, and I wasn't disappointed. If you understand what "bruising" an herb means, or what an atomizer is, come give this place your money.

QEWnTXUunbnkrpsTuCJ4qg.text: Rude staff. Horrible service. Closes earlier than posted times. Do yourself a favor and don't bother visiting the speakeasy. The hotel itself is great- too bad it's stuck with this bar inside it. Go to the tap room instead if you're staying in the hotel.

w-Y0Y49WGB1nFXycUxirpA.text: Speakeasy's are typically known for being quiet, dark, low key hole in the wall establishments however, this one was frustratingly loud and had less than desirable drinks. Pro's were the hot nuts and comfortable lounge chairs, however our "Old Fashioned's" were club soda's diluted with a splash of bourbon.

SbLEy3jD1t6gzvnE1wrNGA.text: I have been to speakeasy bars all over the country...Patterson House, The Violet Hour, Please Don't Tell, etc.  This, my friends, is NOT a speakeasy. This is a hotel bar.  I should have known based on the fact that "speakeasy" was emblazoned on the door of the bar.  My husband and I decided to have a nightcap after a fabulous night of dinner and drinks at Meat and Potatoes (highly recommend).  We found this "speakeasy" on the bottom floor of our hotel and were elated!  We entered and were excited to try the offerings.  After careful consideration, we went with the Pims Cup and a Whiskey concoction which I forget the name.  My husband's drink was $17, so needless to say, he was excited to try it.  The Pim's Cup was a very reasonable $8.50.  We received our drinks after about 15 minutes.  My Pim's cup was served in a wine glass.  It was a dark red and topped with a plethora of fruit (apples, blackberry, ect).  I double checked when our server set it down to make sure I didn't receive someone's sangria.  Our server informed me that it was, in fact, a Pim's Cup.  It was awful.  Tasted like soda water.  My husband (a devout Bourbon drinker from Louisville) said his drink tasted like licorice with no hint of whiskey what so ever.  We contemplated what to do.  We are not used to sending back drinks, but this was ridiculous.  We couldn't choke them down.  We spoke with the server and let him know that we were unhappy with our drinks.  He was visibly dismayed.  My husband asked for an Old Fashioned and I passed for fear of getting another subpar drink.  We heard the bartender speaking ill of the couple that sent back drinks and telling other patrons she takes pride in her drinks.  We were mortified.  We waited 20 minutes and still, my husband had not been served his Old Fashioned.  It was embarrassing and infuriating at the same time.  We decided to leave since we felt very unwelcome.  This is quite possibly the worst bar experience we have ever had.  I warn all patrons accustomed to a certain level of craftsmanship and service when it comes to beverages to stay away.  There are much better places in this city to enjoy an artfully crafted cocktail.

AAfGpOd-t2YvfGhyvwBmzw.text: I don't consider this a Speakeasy.  It just seems like a bar at the bottom of a hotel.  My drink was solid, but the service was deplorable.  I waited forever.  This is the worst Speakeasy that I have ever been to.

CR_bbMNrUG-xCkCB7dsqQw.text: Amazing. DAWN. George. Dave. Great bar and those guys know what they are doing. I ordered no drinks, and let them decide every drink. Each drink was perfect and we really appreciated the personalized experience. Definitely go here if you are in the Pittsburgh area!

yFm2qVfq2RUeDY8K8Fr34g.text: I asked the bartender for "something whiskey but refreshing". She mixed up an off-menu drink with a fresh lemony flavor that didn't overpower the whiskey at all (like a cheap sour mix does)  Excellent service. Wonderful dark and comfortable atmosphere.  My wife ordered a "Michael Collins" and it was even better!

xUIo-bg2zyXqJ_AmawNfLA.text: Something different to check out downtown. Ground floor of William Penn Hotel. Older crowd and chill music. Bartender was very friendly

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Speakeasy in Old William Penn Hotel

5SqUw42H3M75t3meo2NzbA.text: Marvelous cocktails, made by people who respect the ingredients, served in a dark yet appealing establishment...  The only thing keeping this from bring 5 star is the price, but this is, ultimately, a 'hotel' bar, so...  Go there. Enjoy the drinks, soak in the ambiance. Live a little, okay?

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Manhattan... Properly mixed by people who understand and respect the ingredients

txbp0sRCmG3D-4lDmcbOxQ.text: While in town, we happened upon this spot completely by accident. Our rooftop bar was closed for rain so we went searching for another place close by. This place was steps from our hotel. On first impression their hotel entrance is stunning with classic decor. For the bar though, you head straight downstairs at the entrance. What a place! Seemed to be straight out of the prohibition era. Everything made me feel like I had stepped back a hundred years, down to the old-style drink menus, hand-stitched with leather covers. And jazz music. The drinks themselves are modeled after popular cocktails of the time. They were delicious and service was exceptional. What a cool place!

SdoOL0ULT6inoqgjXhbX5A.text: I can understand all the comments about service difficulties; I can see how a place that makes drinks as good as these could get overwhelmed. Dawn makes the best drinks I have had in Pitt. I fly here all the time and don't Yelp the establishments because I have rarely been impressed or massively disappointed. I was impressed. Great drinks; excellent bartender.   Great experience.

vXAJ8VKjyTHujHJzv06F6Q.text: Dawn was AMAZING!!!  She asked what my go-to drink was (Vodka/Club) and whipped up an amazing Gin Old Fashion with this delicious maple froth on top.  She had a lot of knowledge and great charisma!

3j48Urx6X5Ak-6S3FPSKjA.text: The Speakeasy is a small bar in the Omni William Penn Hotel. It is a really small place, but has a nice ambiance about it. The lounge area is setup for small intimate parties, and the bartenders come out to provide personal service to the tables as well as the bar. The lighting is low and the art is reminiscent of a 20's speakeasy.  I went there with a few colleagues and a client after a day or meetings and dinner. It was a pretty nice spot for a Thursday afternoon. Quiet and personal. Between us we had the Moscow Mules, which come in a regular and citrus version. I had one of each and they were both outstanding. My colleagues had a Gin Rickey and Manhattan, both of which were very good according to those imbibing. This was also one of the few places I have been to that has Absinthe (a favorite of mine) and also has the cold water fountain to go along with it, though they are loathe to use it.   I did have two issues with the place though. One was that the drink menu had mostly complicated drinks that take many steps to complete. The drink orders were very slow to arrive after placing. I was typically ordering my next drink when my current was only 1/2 done. Also, it was very easy to hear everyone else conversation. While there was only a few people there at the time, had it been busier I expect it would have been pretty loud, which does not fit with the ambiance if you ask me. Also, a larger crowd would have slowed down the service even more.

YZfhyFYU2U4DIZZajM_mWw.text: Laid back, good cocktails, and intimate. If you like pretending you have sophisticated opinions and money - this is the place to go.

_sD2V8rRj2nt-rm0aDh16A.text: I'm not going to give it a bad review, but I guess when I was hearing about it and envisioning a speakeasy... this just didn't really connect in my mind.  The drinks were ok, but again, only in my opinion, not really that interesting or satisfying.  The time to make a drink is very slow & when it's not busy, hard to understand why.  I ordered a gibson & got an old fashioned so then re-ordered and that was slow coming, too!   It was o.k. The Jack Collins was meh.  The cobblers were lots of muddled fruit & tasty, but hard to drink.  The decor is... meh & the lights were glaring to me.  I didn't get the bare halogen lights strung across the ceiling.  The seating is odd...  Long banquette style benches along the wall, but no real separation and then only footstools and an inconvenient low table.  A couple of four-tops and one two top with big wing chairs in a little alcove, a small, awkward seating area coming in from the entry.  I think the space would be great for an intimate event or gathering, but not really conducive to a 2-3 people coming in and being comfortable or feeling like they're in a speakeasy.  I also think they should limit the music to prohibition-era styles/tunes.  Much more appropriate.  I also think they should have a smart-casual dress code.  That would make it much more of an experience than just seeing everyone in flip-flops & sloppy t-shirts.  I'm sorry if I'm being picky.  I love this hotel & I'm glad they have a space like this, I just think it could be soooo much more!

2Jk7dpG3eJJPXILyPxreTg.text: New to town and found on yelp under restaurant. While they do serve minimal apps., they do not serve food. Otherwise this little gem was a great find. Nice atmosphere with exceptional drink menu. The Moscow Mule was great with fresh ingredients such as ginger, mint & rosemary. Great for an intimate evening or gather of friends.

kaa-bt4l1rImbSjuyOL2dg.text: Very cool place. Music is old school. And i mean like piano silent movie old school. The server is very knowledgeable and they give you free snacks to eat while you sip your beverage. The vodka Collins is to die for. And it had a bbq chip as a decoration. They only thing I can't agree about is the price. $30 is for 2 drinks is a little over the top. Lower the prices to $8 and you'd have a grand slam. This is pittsburgh and not NYC after all. Would highly recommend.

f28b3jbWBX8_xkxx6C5a_w.text: Amazing drinks, amazing staff. The bartender made suggestions for fantastic cocktails I never would have ordered for myself. My group had a great time. Wonderful ambiance too! I'll be back.

eBh-fkK5apuke6kkq5tCsg.text: Unique experience. Super fancy fun place in the bottom floor of the Omni. The bartenders are top notch. The drinks are unique to represent prohibition times and even are made with many local distilled liqueurs on the very same street. The pricing is reasonable and there are many drinks to choose from. Very fun ambiance.

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Absinthe
Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Old fashioned. 90 proof and legit
Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Speakeasy

Q69zGCrRmCh24rtF8m1Cpw.text: Great little place to hole up for a few cocktails off the beaten path. Dark and secluded. Strong drinks. If I was negotiating terms of a defection, this wouldn't be a bad place to either think about it alone, or sign the papers.

Cn3vDFUY05gKxj97_sqh4A.text: The Speakeasy is a neat place. Not a huge beer selection, but they make excellent drinks. During events the bar can quickly fill with people to where the establishment reaches capacity and will not let others in. This is unfortunate, but the bar is a neat place to check out with a small group or with a significant other.

3H-S7_WHg-XeiIDGv2mR6Q.text: The atmosphere here is exactly what I expected..very Mad Men-esque. I had the 18 Liberty, the couple next to us had each other's throats...I think mine was better.  For as swanky a vibe this place has, I expected classier dress and behavior from the clientele.  In case you were wondering, jeans are acceptable, so don't worry about a dress code.  The prices are shockingly average compared to what I expected--$8-15 for a cocktail.

M0OLjCluOC-xz3nqTjy0GA.text: Great location in the bottom of Omni. Hidden in the bottom of the hotel and was an actual speakeasy in prohibition times.    The feel and atmosphere of the bar is relaxed and chill.  The drinks and food are locally sourced and original twists on some ancient and modern classics and surprisingly affordable.  Out waiter was amazing. Highly recommended.

9KX8WQ3o-i1xnRiW9rj8EA.text: Well... The place was understaffed and didn't let people in-- even with their maximum capacity at 47-- they were way below and could not keep up! Head next door to the Commoner at Hotel Monaco! We will stay here next time!

UcX_xOGHxZqwvt1x6AsE5A.text: Nice lounge. Great hotel. Bad service. Like much of Pittsburgh hospitality, waitstaff and bartender seemed unhappy, uncaring and insincere. You would think the William Penn hotel would not allow such bad behavior.

-RxsXHaPq5ikinXUuZ2aTA.text: I don't know who the Thursday night mixologist was (tonight) but she was damn good! There were about 30 people asking for drinks at the same time. She made drink after drink without a break. She did a really good job on dressing up my drink, and made me feel special, so thanks a bunch! The doorman guy was nice too.   Good cocktails take a while to make, so be patient!

HtoQLtoM8RG4vAxmJgSIuQ.text: This hidden gem is located on the bottom floor of the William Penn Hotel. The ambience is romantic and relaxing. The drinks are spectacular and the servers make the experience even more exciting. They are so nice and a pleasure to talk with. You can sit at the bar or find a cozy little spot by yourself. Love the prohibition music, decor and feel. It's definitely worth a visit.

VXA41XuDAvm8rOdwcIl87w.text: A great chill spot to go after work, or after dinner. Dawn is the best bartender in the city!

LsxTNnYHTHyDpqbjMvBl1Q.text: While the ambiance tries hard to be chill, the drinks don't match. Only lasted for one round as wasn't really worth the price.

9ao5YZHCJTN24G8l6QRtHg.text: Meh. Overpay? If you like... this had more of a hotel basement bar feel than a speakeasy. I got basically ignored while I looked over the menu and it was populated with rich business folk. There are just too many better bars to spend your money at IMO. And it is just my opinion so perhaps it was an off night but for me impressions are key.

D4U5y2mm1TKh4rPnfMXPQg.text: Pittsburgh has a lot of bars.  Their South Side is very concentrated in terms of bars and a popular area to hit up for the nightlife scene.  But I'm a speakeasy kind of gal.  I like the quiet and intimate environment and the crafty cocktails that all good speakeasies offer.  Sadly, Pittsburgh only has a small handful of these speakeasies.  Speakeasy is one of the former speakeasies that was restored from the Prohibition Era.  It's located in the basement of the Omni William Penn Hotel.  I wish the entrance was a little more hidden to recreate the experience of entering a speakeasy.  The doors are labeled Speakeasy, which is obviously a dead giveaway.  Service was also lacking despite a small crowd.  There was a 10-15 minute wait for our drinks.  Otherwise, the interior and the drinks were spot on.  We were able to sink into their velvet armchairs in a semi-private nook and sip on our Oktoberfest and Apricot Sparkling Gimlet, letting the night swallow us in.

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Bar
Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Cocktails!
Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Speakeasy. Labeled so not very well hidden.

cojIYg_ZH_f-rJEQH2NT2g.text: I cannot say enough about how awesome the location of this bar is! The decor, furniture, history is amazing! The reason I give this only 3 stars is because the service was poor and the bartenders do not do well at making these cocktails that are on their menu. The back bar was in total disarray and there were dirty dishes everywhere. If someone can get in there with great mixologists and knowing how to organize the liquor behind the bar and get someone to wash dishes, this place will be True hotspot for Pittsburgh! I hope it works out, because they have a perfect location in a beautiful hotel!

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States
Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States

YXi50QMfNsRUeWktEm4FZg.text: This was a real disappointment. Met a friend for drinks after a day of business, having heard the Speakeasy was a good spot for quality cocktails. While the space is comfortable enough, everything else is off, starting with the faux red velvet rope experience at the door. Ordered a Sazerac, expecting a classic cocktail presentation using a few local spirits. What I got was a watery over sweet mess garnishes with limp bits of lemon and orange peel and a licorice candy that the server said was meant to accent the anise notes in the drink. What?? If you're going to charge $17 in Pittsburgh for a cocktail, which is ridiculous on its own, at least execute a classic correctly. I expect there are some worthy cocktail bars in this city. The Speakeasy is not one of them.

-bFz_qkYXjvzpZfOmtUgxw.text: This is a cool spot in the lower level of the Omni hotel. I would give it a 4 if I were a hotel guest for the convenience of having not just this speakeasy but plenty other bars/attractions in the hotel (especially in the winter).  Hubby and I checked this Speakeasy out on a Fri late night, at my request. And we got there bit past midnight and it was kinda empty :(. The ambiance was still neat and timey like you'd expect. The cocktails were good but nothing outta this world. Price point was standard for a cocktail bar. Good variety of drinks on the menu and altogether a pretty bar and seating area. Wish it would've been much more lively!

Xm3ZPmBgCGgir_hVviTLnQ.text: We checked out the Speakeasy a few times while we were staying at the Omni Penn for a work conference. I liked that it never got too crowded, even on Friday and Saturday night. They also had a nice selection of drinks. We had a great server, Dave, but i'm knocking off a star for the rest of the staff. One bartender was downright rude and the rest acted very dismissive. Overall though, this is a great place to grab a drink if you're staying in the area.

y_LABP6UnuLff-pyLIiHzA.text: The ambiance makes this place. Perfect for an after dinner cocktail. We had to wait at the doors until there was room inside. Honestly, I think that is a smart play by management because when we were late escorted to our table by the bouncer, we had nothing but stellar service. Controlling the numbers keeps service good and also stays True to a traditional speakeasy where waiting at the door is part of the experience.   Manhattan was great!

LiQv-7g3ImM6ySQ_rzoZJQ.text: Loved the environment and the specialty drinks! The Tom Collins were amazing with house made sour mix.

0S0lwVRBpTarmxBZDIE2fQ.text: Small quiet bar in the basement of the William Penn. I understand the idea of a speakeasy is to be secret but it's kinda boring. The place smelled when I was there too. Good drinks.

rS_uIFKluYu01gjHcn_AYw.text: Dirty, poor service and bad cocktails.  So unfortunate. I've been a couple different times hoping it was just a bad night.  But, it is consistently Bad.  Plenty of nice places in Pittsburgh. This just isn't one of them.

VrSiiF0mEi8T3dNW7X1yUw.text: Speakeasy is quite easy to find nowadays, as signs in Omni will point you to the right direction.  During my first visit, I was told the room was vacant for decades before it was rediscovered.  It used to be a legit speakeasy.  The bartenders here are humorous and pour heavy.  The drinks are delicious and strong.  If you want to try an appetizer along, I recommend their pesto mozzarella.  Speakeasy is one of my favorite spots to grab a fancy drink.  I find it economical and calorie-friendly since one drink is enough and two drinks can be too much for me!

hnx4t4bXQTFzd6A3uFsziA.text: If you're looking for an authentic speakeasy experience, this is not the place.   The speakeasy is not even remotely hidden. It's located in a well-lit basement of the Omni William Penn Hotel with the name ("speakeasy") branded all over the door. Also, a speakeasy named "speakeasy", really? To me, this place has more of a hotel basement bar feel than an actual speakeasy. We ordered the mescal old fashioned and the apricot sparkling gimlet. Between these two drinks, I recommend the mescal old fashioned if you're looking for something with a more unique taste, and the apricot sparkling gimlet if you're looking for something more refreshing. I personally prefers the mescal old fashioned over the apricot sparkling gimlet. The cayenne simple syrup in the drink definitely gives it a really nice kick, while the gimlet tastes a bit underwhelming to me. Drinks were about $15/each if cost is a concern of yours. We had no complaints in regards to service, though our drinks took awhile to come out despite the place being almost empty.

pnA028arAlWmKUQfQ6_u-g.text: The experience at Speakeasy was fabulous. The cocktails were delicious and the banter with bartender Dawn was memorable. Make a point to visit Speakeasy whenever you're in Pittburgh.

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Blanton neat

WNkobFVTm7aABUxgQ-H6HA.text: Better than your average hotel bar, with very nice dimly lit atmosphere. The cocktail list is long, and the drinks were pretty good. A very strong old fashioned, and the moscow mule comes in the proper mule mug with some solid ginger flavor.  What keeps them from being a top notch place is that the bartenders get overly flustered when there are more than a handful of people here. The chaos behind the bar brings the vibe down if you are sitting at the bar, and they are quite slow. Still, if you're staying in the Omni, it's worth checking out.

sgYL-hRZkN6YBSxweEep1Q.text: Beautiful set up and great location. Drinks were delicious. Can't wait to go back. Definitely a place you want to dress up for.

NggJQYgdjn-KBBQk4p9PRQ.text: We've now tried this spot on three separate trips to Pittsburgh and, unfortunately, the results each time have been the same - We were ignored for 5-10 minutes after sitting down at a table, despite the bar and room not being busy.  Once we were acknowledged and served, the cocktails were less than mediocre.  I won't nit-pick the details, or the pricing, but will instead just say we haven't enjoyed any of the drinks.  That, coupled with sterile service, leads us to knowing we will not back.

cnIQB-v6SzeXC6bLe6a3FA.text: Super secret Speakeasy. Small, dark and chill.   I got a Sidecar with a rock candy garnish. It was yummy.   Out of a few beers, so if you want that. Forget about it.   My friend got a Mule and she thought it was perfect.   It's a little louder than I expected because it was well packed for a random Tuesday night.

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Sidecar with rock candy.

HqNWX9pTj0dkM3XjkgzZiQ.text: I finally dropped by here on a random Thursday night. I was recently on a cruise where I was trying all the old prohibition classics and tried a side car. Although I liked it, I wanted to try it when it was made at a speakeasy or something like that an the speakeasy at the Omni William Penn was perfect for that.   It was a nice relaxing night, great conversation and charcuterie board (special of the week) was a wonderful pairing. I also tried their Manhattan (my normal go-to) and it was equally well made.   Only negative is that I feel like this place would be a hit or miss and you can't really plan to go there. By the time we left at 9 pm on a Thursday they were at max capacity (47 people - due to fire codes). If I wanted to take people for drinks I know I would have to have a plan B in place as well, because getting a seat is never going to be an absolute.

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States

S7zsTJkjfyKHOfg37_IaRw.text: Easily one of my favorite bars in Pittsburgh and Dawn, the bartender, is amazing!  The Speakeasy at the Omni William Penn is perfect for groups and special occasions and I've never had a subpar experience here. From the service, to the quality of the drinks and the ambiance, and even down to the sweet/salty bar snacks, everything has always been nothing but perfect.   This is one of the few bars in the city that really offers the "speakeasy vibe" that I'm usually looking for in a bar, as well as the caliber of classic cocktails (Old Fashioneds, Manhattans, Vieux Carres, etc.)   * Parking: Street parking downtown can be a little tricky unless you come late at night; hotel valet is always an option though.  * Pro Tip: The Speakeasy doesn't offer reservations, so having to wait on a crowded night is a possibility, but thankfully I've been lucky (and usually come late night) and have never had to wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States
Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Appetizers: Hummus and the Meat/Cheese Plate

jTwAjb1Vv8mdWnJQ1Kxfgg.text: What a great place! Small and dark like a good speakeasy should be. Dawn, the bartender, makes this place!  She doesn't take anything from anyone and if you are on her good side, she'll make you amazing cocktails not on the menu!  Ask her for a Gin Old Fashioned. You won't be disappointed!

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States
Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States

n5VmGuiXiaCEZmpiRzwb2A.text: This is a good bar! Not really a Speakeasy - although it may have been one decades ago. Dawn is a wonderful person and great bartender. She really helped make the time there fun. They have some pretty good hot nut mix.

BANRoiwSIU6LleBXZQO7Gw.text: Authentic to the bone. Hipsters turn to dust. Dawn is a professional angel of the spirit world, and an absolute master of life.

Cboaz6NHwh2F8Qmzyt2sXw.text: Wow, what an incredibly cool bar hidden away at the William Penn hotel! My friend recommended this place and we stopped by after attending Pittsburgh's Beerfest last weekend. Needless to say I didn't have a lot to drink here after being at Beerfest all evening- but I did sample a few of my friend's cocktails and they were fabulous. The service here was excellent and the ambiance could not be cozier. This spot was an actual speakeasy back in the day, making it an even more unique experience. I can't wait to come back!

MtXwPKURk8B7qwdT_mfZcg.text: Oh, such a super fun concept, deftly executed, with some caveats.  It is indeed quiet, relaxing, and super chill. It doesn't quite have the actual 'speakeasy' feel like some modern speakeasy style places I've been to (with hidden entrances, fake passwords, etc.) but it is a cubbyhole and is cozy as hell.   Yes, you'll spend ninety-eleven dollars on cocktails that aren't really that special. But it's a fun stop.  It's *not* a good place to meet people, but if you are already with the people you're drinking with, fun.  Note that they have a limited capacity so if you arrive later in the evening you may have to wait. Just pretend the Revenooers could bust in at any time and the wait will go faster.

vYp5OkCcmiVicWZnPXmv_A.text: Fun vibe, different decor, dark lighting with music from days past set this place apart. But, it's hard to read drink menu. Great cocktails - I had the Sidecar, listed as one of the popular drinks from the prohibition.  Very good service, nuts are placed at table as you are treated- nice touch. We loved the place but wanted food so, only stayed for one drink. The scotch was great (according to my husband.)

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Cool info about prohibition at the Speakeasy. Had to take a pic so I could actually read it
Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States. Signage showing you where to go

hKrf9BxhGkeS_mTniBS-Ag.text: Dawn is........ quite simply........... the best.  That's all.  Come here. She's such a pro.

-eshQxrWTDb1unisbJF9lQ.text: Escape from reality, sneak downstairs under the lobby and slide into this little hideaway.  Dark and cozy, smells of roasted nuts and perspiration.  Order something that someone invented long ago during a time of mixological taboos.  Glance around the room at the other patrons just sipping the hours away, until the world calls them back.  The energy here is self reflective and calming, which only adds to its value.  I shall return

8R6G39gslScJGtkUhvw20A.text: I had been wanting to stop in at this bar and will say glad I did!  Yes, it's low key and rather dark but the drinks are excellent!  There is an amazing bartender at this location and she makes the absolute best drinks and makes her own fresh Lemmon juice! Hard worker and a great person! I'm looking forward to coming to town to make a stop here again and hope she is working when I do stop by.  If your on the fence go...I really liked it!

GLXYBC1ioqnlCAKxJkOoXA.text: Oh my goodness this is my new favorite place for drinks. I'm not sure how I didn't know this place existed but I absolutely love it! It is right up my alley. We came here in a pretty large group this past Saturday to celebrate a friends birthday. The place is definitely small but that was nice for our group. Because of how small it is it doesn't get overly crowded like most bars where you stand on top of people. They only let so many people in so you are guaranteed to have space to breath.  The drink options were amazing as well. I only had the chance to try the Old Fashioned but I saw many of the drinks my friends ordered and they all looked delicious.

uA7RHf6DA50IESnJ17lwuw.text: First off Dawn is incredible. She made such a delicious and refreshing drink. I really enjoyed myself here. Very low back and friendly atmosphere. Real grown and sexy once you enter those doors. The doors says it all! Shh!! Grown folks here!!! I love it ! The fashion decor and furniture is marvelous! I want to come back!

uo5d9heOBgQMhIkBqoRgig.text: Really cool atmosphere. The bartender was excellent! She was so friendly and knowledgeable! Took her advice on the seasonal punch! It was excellent!

-l2ggRf7lurxYLQNi15gVQ.text: Great place if you are looking for a small, quieter place to chill. Dim lighting and jazz playing. Good whiskey selection. Classic cocktail menu. Friendly service.  Take  the elevator to the WP floor (down) and walk toward the front door of the hotel (will Penn street) and it's on the right.

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States

WRf7L6noTUkfdr4gIKUJtw.text: What a disappointment.  This place is a poor rip off of a real speakeasy, and offers none of the exclusive flair.  The Old Fashioned was overpriced, cheap bourbon poured over too much hotel ice with a chunk of orange.  No finesse - get a double of bourbon instead to save a few bucks.  The Sidecar tasted like a Flavor Ice popsicle before it's put in the freezer.  It's really sad that the resident Starbucks is the best place to get a drink in this beautiful hotel.

BfVB3tArj-631lQrM9I2nw.text: Loved this spot.  Dark classy atmosphere had me feeling completely relaxed.  Tried 4 house drinks they were all very yummy.  Service was good to.  Wish they had a few more food options but over all I'll definitely be back.

photos.caption: Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States
Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States
Photo of Speakeasy - Downtown, PA, United States

8xmbkRRZghoQKAoPuMwnxQ.text: As folks who love a good classic cocktail & the service / knowledge that comes with it, we were SUPER excited to try this spot out. The hotel is epic, historic and gorgeously decorated......then down to the basement level where you will find Speakeasy.   Unfortunately, the decor in the space is very modernized, no one was dressed up, and the $20 cocktails were put together carelessly.   No one should be serving an Old Fashioned with 1/4 of a section of orange (pith included) jammed into a rocks glass with hotel ice machine chips...murky, ugly...served on a dirty glass topped table.   I could go on and on about the other cocktails we tried however, they were all just "ok" or were actually hideous to look at - the antithesis of a good cocktail IMHO.   Overpriced, no class, unfriendly / aloof staff, slightly dirty (as in not cleaned well) and 1995 style prohibition decor (not cool). We will not return to speakeasy, the lobby of the hotel is a much more romantic and beautiful place to enjoy a cocktail.

xOX1xZCqRw5Bi-UBG70ZMw.text: Located below our hotel was an exclusive, dim lit, cocktail bar called speakeasy.   Ingenious name, I know.   The place is actually very nice. With top of the line drinks, good service, and nice decor. Our server gave excellent recommendations. After a long week of whiskey and red meat, my stomach needed something more refreshing. I got some dark and stormies.  Our drinks were accompanied with some snacks. Perfect to munch on seeing how I wasn't planning on eating much that evening. The two seats were perfect for two people people wrapping up nice vacation.   My only knock was the service was a drop slow. I understand fine cocktails like these take awhile to make, but that wasn't the issue. I felt there were times we weren't checked on for awhile. After we were ready to go, it took awhile for them to even walk around for us to let them know we were ready. Still, and excellent time.
